Notes.Text:
This update for haproxy to version 1.8.15 fixes the following issues:

Security issues fixed:

- CVE-2018-20102: Fixed an out-of-bounds read in dns_validate_dns_response(),
  which allowed for memory disclosure (bsc#1119368)
- CVE-2018-20103: Fixed an infinite recursion via crafted packet allows stack
  exhaustion and denial of service (bsc#1119419)

Other notable bug fixes:

- Fix off-by-one write in dns_validate_dns_response()
- Fix out-of-bounds read via signedness error in dns_validate_dns_response()
- Prevent out-of-bounds read in dns_validate_dns_response()
- Prevent out-of-bounds read in dns_read_name()
- Prevent stack-exhaustion via recursion loop in dns_read_name

For a full list of changes, please refer to:
  https://www.haproxy.org/download/1.8/src/CHANGELOG
Notes.Title: Details

Notes.Title: Terms of Use

Relationships.RelatesToProductReference: SUSE Linux Enterprise High Availability Extension 15

Vulnerabilities.Description: An out-of-bounds read in dns_validate_dns_response in dns.c was discovered in HAProxy through 1.8.14. Due to a missing check when validating DNS responses, remote attackers might be able read the 16 bytes corresponding to an AAAA record from the non-initialized part of the buffer, possibly accessing anything that was left on the stack, or even past the end of the 8193-byte buffer, depending on the value of accepted_payload_size.

ProductID: SUSE Linux Enterprise High Availability Extension 15:haproxy-1.8.15~git0.6b6a350a-3.6.2

Vulnerabilities.Description: An issue was discovered in dns.c in HAProxy through 1.8.14. In the case of a compressed pointer, a crafted packet can trigger infinite recursion by making the pointer point to itself, or create a long chain of valid pointers resulting in stack exhaustion.

ProductID: SUSE Linux Enterprise High Availability Extension 15:haproxy-1.8.15~git0.6b6a350a-3.6.2
